## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/context-doc/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

- –ù–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞: `any`, `eslint-disable`, `ts-ignore`
- `unknown`: –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –Ω–∞ boundary (SHELL) –∫–∞–∫ –≤—Ö–æ–¥ –≤ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ (–Ω–∞–ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä, `@effect/schema`);
  –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏–Ω–≥–∞ `unknown` –Ω–µ –¥–æ–ª–∂–µ–Ω –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å –Ω–∞—Ä—É–∂—É boundary-–º–æ–¥—É–ª—è
- `as`: –∑–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â—ë–Ω –≤ –æ–±—ã—á–Ω–æ–º –∫–æ–¥–µ; –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –≤ –æ–¥–Ω–æ–º ‚Äú–∞–∫—Å–∏–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–º‚Äù –º–æ–¥—É–ª–µ (–±—Ä–µ–Ω–¥—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç–æ—Ä—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç–∞–Ω—Ç—ã),

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/context-doc/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

/**
 * @since 1.0.0
 */
import * as Brand from "effect/Brand"
import type { Tag } from "effect/Context"
import * as Context from "effect/Context"
import * as Data from "effect/Data"
import type * as Effect from "effect/Effect"
import type { Layer } from "effect/Layer"
import type { Option } from "effect/Option"
import type { Scope } from "effect/Scope"
import type { Sink } from "effect/Sink"
import type { Stream } from "effect/Stream"
import type { PlatformError } from "./Error.js"
import * as internal from "./internal/fileSystem.js"

/**
 * @since 1.0.0
 * @category model
 */
export interface FileSystem {
  /**
   * Check if a file can be accessed.
   * You can optionally specify the level of access to check for.
   */
  readonly access: (
    path: string,
    options?: AccessFileOptions
  ) => Effect.Effect<void, PlatformError>
  /**
   * Copy a file or directory from `fromPath` to `toPath`.
   *
   * Equivalent to `cp -r`.
   */
  readonly copy: (
    fromPath: string,
    toPath: string,
    options?: CopyOptions
  ) => Effect.Effect<void, PlatformError>
  /**
   * Copy a file from `fromPath` to `toPath`.
   */
  readonly copyFile: (
    fromPath: string,
    toPath: string
  ) => Effect.Effect<void, PlatformError>
  /**
   * Change the permissions of a file.
   */
  readonly chmod: (
    path: string,
    mode: number
  ) => Effect.Effect<void, PlatformError>
  /**
   * Change the owner and group of a file.
   */
  readonly chown: (
    path: string,
    uid: number,
    gid: number
  ) => Effect.Effect<void, PlatformError>
  /**
   * Check if a path exists.
   */
  readonly exists: (
    path: string
  ) => Effect.Effect<boolean, PlatformError>
  /**
   * Create a hard link from `fromPath` to `toPath`.
   */
  readonly link: (
    fromPath: string,
    toPath: string
  ) => Effect.Effect<void, PlatformError>
  /**
   * Create a directory at `path`. You can optionally specify the mode and
   * whether to recursively create nested directories.
   */
  readonly makeDirectory: (
    path: string,
    options?: MakeDirectoryOptions
  ) => Effect.Effect<void, PlatformError>
  /**
   * Create a temporary directory.
   *
   * By default the directory will be created inside the system's default
   * temporary directory, but you can specify a different location by setting
   * the `directory` option.
   *
   * You can also specify a prefix for the directory name by setting the
   * `prefix` option.
   */
  readonly makeTempDirectory: (
    options?: MakeTempDirectoryOptions
  ) => Effect.Effect<string, PlatformError>
  /**
   * Create a temporary directory inside a scope.
   *
   * Functionally equivalent to `makeTempDirectory`, but the directory will be
   * automatically deleted when the scope is closed.
   */
  readonly makeTempDirectoryScoped: (
    options?: MakeTempDirectoryOptions
  ) => Effect.Effect<string, PlatformError, Scope>
  /**
   * Create a temporary file.
   * The directory creation is functionally equivalent to `makeTempDirectory`.
   * The file name will be a randomly generated string.
   */
  readonly makeTempFile: (
    options?: MakeTempFileOptions
  ) => Effect.Effect<string, PlatformError>
  /**
   * Create a temporary file inside a scope.
   *
   * Functionally equivalent to `makeTempFile`, but the file will be
   * automatically deleted when the scope is closed.
   */
  readonly makeTempFileScoped: (
    options?: MakeTempFileOptions
  ) => Effect.Effect<string, PlatformError, Scope>
  /**
   * Open a file at `path` with the specified `options`.
   *
   * The file handle will be automatically closed when the scope is closed.
   */
  readonly open: (
    path: string,
    options?: OpenFileOptions
  ) => Effect.Effect<File, PlatformError, Scope>
  /**
   * List the contents of a directory.
   *
   * You can recursively list the contents of nested directories by setting the
   * `recursive` option.
   */
  readonly readDirectory: (
    path: string,
    options?: ReadDirectoryOptions
  ) => Effect.Effect<Array<string>, PlatformError>
  /**
   * Read the contents of a file.
   */
  readonly readFile: (
    path: string
  ) => Effect.Effect<Uint8Array, PlatformError>
  /**
   * Read the contents of a file.
   */
  readonly readFileString: (
    path: string,
    encoding?: string
  ) => Effect.Effect<string, PlatformError>
  /**
   * Read the destination of a symbolic link.
   */
  readonly readLink: (
    path: string
  ) => Effect.Effect<string, PlatformError>
  /**
   * Resolve a path to its canonicalized absolute pathname.
   */
  readonly realPath: (
    path: string
  ) => Effect.Effect<string, PlatformError>
  /**
   * Remove a file or directory.
   */
  readonly remove: (
    path: string,
    options?: RemoveOptions
  ) => Effect.Effect<void, PlatformError>
  /**
   * Rename a file or directory.
   */
  readonly rename: (
    oldPath: string,
    newPath: string
  ) => Effect.Effect<void, PlatformError>
  /**
   * Create a writable `Sink` for the specified `path`.
   */
  readonly sink: (
    path: string,
    options?: SinkOptions
  ) => Sink<void, Uint8Array, never, PlatformError>
  /**
   * Get information about a file at `path`.
   */
  readonly stat: (
    path: string
  ) => Effect.Effect<File.Info, PlatformError>
  /**
   * Create a readable `Stream` for the specified `path`.
   *
   * Changing the `bufferSize` option will change the internal buffer size of
   * the stream. It defaults to `4`.
   *
   * The `chunkSize` option will change the size of the chunks emitted by the
   * stream. It defaults to 64kb.

```typescript
    pipe(
      sendMessageUseCase(validCommand),
      Effect.provide(MockMessageRepository),
      Effect.provide(MockNotificationService),
      Effect.tap((messageId) =>
        Effect.sync(() => {
          expect(messageId).toEqual(expectedMessageId)
        })
      ),
      Effect.asVoid
    )
  )
})
```

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/context-doc/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

- –ù–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞: `any`, `eslint-disable`, `ts-ignore`
- `unknown`: –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –Ω–∞ boundary (SHELL) –∫–∞–∫ –≤—Ö–æ–¥ –≤ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ (–Ω–∞–ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä, `@effect/schema`);
  –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏–Ω–≥–∞ `unknown` –Ω–µ –¥–æ–ª–∂–µ–Ω –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å –Ω–∞—Ä—É–∂—É boundary-–º–æ–¥—É–ª—è
- `as`: –∑–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â—ë–Ω –≤ –æ–±—ã—á–Ω–æ–º –∫–æ–¥–µ; –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –≤ –æ–¥–Ω–æ–º ‚Äú–∞–∫—Å–∏–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–º‚Äù –º–æ–¥—É–ª–µ (–±—Ä–µ–Ω–¥—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç–æ—Ä—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç–∞–Ω—Ç—ã),
  –¥–∞–ª—å—à–µ –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –±–µ–∑ –∫–∞—Å—Ç–æ–≤
- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞: –∏—Å—á–µ—Ä–ø—ã–≤–∞—é—â–∏–π –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ union types —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `.exhaustive()` / `Match.exhaustive`
- –í–Ω–µ—à–Ω–∏–µ –∑–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–µ–π—Å—ã
- –û—à–∏–±–∫–∏: —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Å–∏–≥–Ω–∞—Ç—É—Ä–∞—Ö —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–π, –Ω–µ runtime exceptions

üß¨ **–ú–û–ù–ê–î–ò–ß–ï–°–ö–ê–Ø –ö–û–ú–ü–û–ó–ò–¶–ò–Ø**:

- Effect-TS –¥–ª—è –≤—Å–µ—Ö —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤: `Effect<Success, Error, Requirements>`
- –ö–æ–º–ø–æ–∑–∏—Ü–∏—è —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `pipe()` –∏ `Effect.flatMap()`
- Dependency injection —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ Layer pattern
- –û–±—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∫–∞ –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫ –±–µ–∑ try/catch
- –ó–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â–µ–Ω–æ –≤ –ø—Ä–æ–¥—É–∫—Ç-–∫–æ–¥–µ: `async/await`, raw Promise chains (`then/catch`), `Promise.all`
- Interop —Å Promise/–∏—Å–∫–ª—é—á–µ–Ω–∏—è–º–∏ ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –≤ SHELL —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.try` / `Effect.tryPromise` (—Å —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–º –º–∞–ø–ø–∏–Ω–≥–æ–º –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫)
- –†–µ—Å—É—Ä—Å—ã —Å —Ñ–∏–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑–∞—Ü–∏–µ–π ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.acquireRelease` + `Effect.scoped`

–û–ë–Ø–ó–ê–¢–ï–õ–¨–ù–´–ï –¢–†–ï–ë–û–í–ê–ù–ò–Ø:
‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê

1. **–ß–ò–°–¢–û–¢–ê –§–£–ù–ö–¶–ò–ô**:

```typescript
// ‚úÖ –ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - —á–∏—Å—Ç–∞—è —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏—è (–±–µ–∑ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤, –±–µ–∑ –º—É—Ç–∞—Ü–∏–π)
type Money = number

const calculateTotal = (items: ReadonlyArray<Item>): Money =>
  items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)

// ‚ùå –ù–ï–ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - –Ω–∞—Ä—É—à–µ–Ω–∏–µ —á–∏—Å—Ç–æ—Ç—ã

  console.log("Calculating total") // –ü–û–ë–û–ß–ù–´–ô –≠–§–§–ï–ö–¢!
  return items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)
}
```

2. **–§–£–ù–ö–¶–ò–û–ù–ê–õ–¨–ù–´–ï –ö–û–ú–ú–ï–ù–¢–ê–†–ò–ò**:

```typescript
// CHANGE: <–∫—Ä–∞—Ç–∫–æ–µ –æ–ø–∏—Å–∞–Ω–∏–µ –∏–∑–º–µ–Ω–µ–Ω–∏—è>
// WHY: <–º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–µ/–∞—Ä—Ö–∏—Ç–µ–∫—Ç—É—Ä–Ω–æ–µ –æ–±–æ—Å–Ω–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ>
// QUOTE(–¢–ó): "<–¥–æ—Å–ª–æ–≤–Ω–∞—è —Ü–∏—Ç–∞—Ç–∞ —Ç—Ä–µ–±–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏—è>" | n/a
// REF: <REQ-ID –∏–∑ RTM –∏–ª–∏ –Ω–æ–º–µ—Ä —Å–æ–æ–±—â–µ–Ω–∏—è>
// SOURCE: <—Å—Å—ã–ª–∫–∞ —Å –¥–æ—Å–ª–æ–≤–Ω–æ–π —Ü–∏—Ç–∞—Ç–æ–π –∏–∑ –≤–Ω–µ—à–Ω–µ–≥–æ –∏—Å—Ç–æ—á–Ω–∏–∫–∞> | n/a
// FORMAT THEOREM: <‚àÄx ‚àà Domain: P(x) ‚Üí Q(f(x))>
// PURITY: CORE | SHELL - —è–≤–Ω–∞—è –º–∞—Ä–∫–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∫–∞ —Å–ª–æ—è
// EFFECT: Effect<Success, Error, Requirements> - –¥–ª—è shell —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–π
// INVARIANT: <–º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–π –∏–Ω–≤–∞—Ä–∏–∞–Ω—Ç —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏>
// COMPLEXITY: O(time)/O(space) - –≤—Ä–µ–º–µ–Ω–Ω–∞—è –∏ –ø—Ä–æ—Å—Ç—Ä–∞–Ω—Å—Ç–≤–µ–Ω–Ω–∞—è —Å–ª–æ–∂–Ω–æ—Å—Ç—å
```

3. **–°–¢–†–û–ì–ê–Ø –î–û–ö–£–ú–ï–ù–¢–ê–¶–ò–Ø –¢–ò–ü–û–í**:

```typescript
/**
 * –û—Ç–ø—Ä–∞–≤–ª—è–µ—Ç —Å–æ–æ–±—â–µ–Ω–∏–µ –≤ —á–∞—Ç —Å –≥–∞—Ä–∞–Ω—Ç–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω–æ–π –¥–æ—Å—Ç–∞–≤–∫–æ–π
 *
 * @param message - –í–∞–ª–∏–¥–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω–æ–µ —Å–æ–æ–±—â–µ–Ω–∏–µ (–Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º–æ–µ)
 * @param recipients - –ü–æ–ª—É—á–∞—Ç–µ–ª–∏ (non-empty array)
 * @returns Effect —Å MessageId –∏–ª–∏ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω–æ–π –æ—à–∏–±–∫–æ–π
 *
 * @pure false - —Å–æ–¥–µ—Ä–∂–∏—Ç —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã –æ—Ç–ø—Ä–∞–≤–∫–∏
 * @effect DatabaseService, NotificationService
 * @invariant ‚àÄm ‚àà Messages: sent(m) ‚Üí ‚àÉid: persisted(m, id)
 * @precondition message.content.length > 0 ‚àß recipients.length > 0
 * @postcondition ‚àÄr ‚àà recipients: notified(r, message) ‚à® error_logged(r)
 * @complexity O(n) where n = |recipients|
 * @throws Never - –≤—Å–µ –æ—à–∏–±–∫–∏ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ Effect
 */
```

4. **–ò–°–ß–ï–†–ü–´–í–ê–Æ–©–ò–ô –ü–ê–¢–¢–ï–†–ù-–ú–ê–¢–ß–ò–ù–ì**:

```typescript
// Switch statements are forbidden in functional programming paradigm.
// How to fix: Use Match with exhaustive coverage.
// Example:
import { Match } from "effect"

type Item = { type: "this" } | { type: "that" }

const result = Match.value(item).pipe(
  Match.when({ type: "this" }, (it) => processThis(it)),
  Match.when({ type: "that" }, (it) => processThat(it)),
  Match.exhaustive
)
```

5. **–≠–§–§–ï–ö–¢–ù–ê–Ø –ê–†–•–ò–¢–ï–ö–¢–£–†–ê**:

```typescript
// CORE: –ß–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–µ–π—Å—ã
interface MessageRepository {

  ) => Effect.Effect<Option<Message>, DatabaseError>

// SHELL: –ö–æ–Ω–∫—Ä–µ—Ç–Ω–∞—è —Ä–µ–∞–ª–∏–∑–∞—Ü–∏—è
```

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/context-doc/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

- –ù–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞: `any`, `eslint-disable`, `ts-ignore`
- `unknown`: –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –Ω–∞ boundary (SHELL) –∫–∞–∫ –≤—Ö–æ–¥ –≤ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ (–Ω–∞–ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä, `@effect/schema`);
  –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏–Ω–≥–∞ `unknown` –Ω–µ –¥–æ–ª–∂–µ–Ω –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å –Ω–∞—Ä—É–∂—É boundary-–º–æ–¥—É–ª—è
- `as`: –∑–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â—ë–Ω –≤ –æ–±—ã—á–Ω–æ–º –∫–æ–¥–µ; –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –≤ –æ–¥–Ω–æ–º ‚Äú–∞–∫—Å–∏–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–º‚Äù –º–æ–¥—É–ª–µ (–±—Ä–µ–Ω–¥—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç–æ—Ä—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç–∞–Ω—Ç—ã),
  –¥–∞–ª—å—à–µ –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –±–µ–∑ –∫–∞—Å—Ç–æ–≤
- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞: –∏—Å—á–µ—Ä–ø—ã–≤–∞—é—â–∏–π –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ union types —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `.exhaustive()` / `Match.exhaustive`
- –í–Ω–µ—à–Ω–∏–µ –∑–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–µ–π—Å—ã
- –û—à–∏–±–∫–∏: —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Å–∏–≥–Ω–∞—Ç—É—Ä–∞—Ö —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–π, –Ω–µ runtime exceptions

üß¨ **–ú–û–ù–ê–î–ò–ß–ï–°–ö–ê–Ø –ö–û–ú–ü–û–ó–ò–¶–ò–Ø**:

- Effect-TS –¥–ª—è –≤—Å–µ—Ö —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤: `Effect<Success, Error, Requirements>`
- –ö–æ–º–ø–æ–∑–∏—Ü–∏—è —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `pipe()` –∏ `Effect.flatMap()`

- –û–±—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∫–∞ –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫ –±–µ–∑ try/catch
- –ó–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â–µ–Ω–æ –≤ –ø—Ä–æ–¥—É–∫—Ç-–∫–æ–¥–µ: `async/await`, raw Promise chains (`then/catch`), `Promise.all`
- Interop —Å Promise/–∏—Å–∫–ª—é—á–µ–Ω–∏—è–º–∏ ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –≤ SHELL —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.try` / `Effect.tryPromise` (—Å —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–º –º–∞–ø–ø–∏–Ω–≥–æ–º –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫)
- –†–µ—Å—É—Ä—Å—ã —Å —Ñ–∏–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑–∞—Ü–∏–µ–π ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.acquireRelease` + `Effect.scoped`

–û–ë–Ø–ó–ê–¢–ï–õ–¨–ù–´–ï –¢–†–ï–ë–û–í–ê–ù–ò–Ø:
‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê

1. **–ß–ò–°–¢–û–¢–ê –§–£–ù–ö–¶–ò–ô**:

```typescript
// ‚úÖ –ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - —á–∏—Å—Ç–∞—è —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏—è (–±–µ–∑ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤, –±–µ–∑ –º—É—Ç–∞—Ü–∏–π)
type Money = number

const calculateTotal = (items: ReadonlyArray<Item>): Money =>
  items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)

// ‚ùå –ù–ï–ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - –Ω–∞—Ä—É—à–µ–Ω–∏–µ —á–∏—Å—Ç–æ—Ç—ã

  console.log("Calculating total") // –ü–û–ë–û–ß–ù–´–ô –≠–§–§–ï–ö–¢!
  return items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)
}
```

2. **–§–£–ù–ö–¶–ò–û–ù–ê–õ–¨–ù–´–ï –ö–û–ú–ú–ï–ù–¢–ê–†–ò–ò**:


## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/context-doc/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

/**
 * @since 1.0.0
 */
import type * as Cause from "effect/Cause"
import * as Data from "effect/Data"
import * as Predicate from "effect/Predicate"
import * as Schema from "effect/Schema"
import type { Simplify } from "effect/Types"

/**
 * @since 1.0.0
 * @category type id
 */
export const TypeId: unique symbol = Symbol.for("@effect/platform/Error")

/**
 * @since 1.0.0
 * @category type id
 */
export type TypeId = typeof TypeId

/**
 * @since 1.0.0
 * @category refinements
 */
export const isPlatformError = (u: unknown): u is PlatformError => Predicate.hasProperty(u, TypeId)

/**
 * @since 1.0.0
 * @category error
 */
export const TypeIdError = <const TypeId extends symbol, const Tag extends string>(
  typeId: TypeId,
  tag: Tag
): new<A extends Record<string, any>>(
  args: Simplify<A>
) =>
  & Cause.YieldableError
  & Record<TypeId, TypeId>
  & { readonly _tag: Tag }
  & Readonly<A> =>
{
  class Base extends Data.Error<{}> {
    readonly _tag = tag
  }
  ;(Base.prototype as any)[typeId] = typeId
  ;(Base.prototype as any).name = tag
  return Base as any
}

/**
 * @since 1.0.0
 * @category Models
 */
export const Module = Schema.Literal(
  "Clipboard",
  "Command",
  "FileSystem",
  "KeyValueStore",
  "Path",
  "Stream",
  "Terminal"
)

/**
 * @since 1.0.0
 * @category Models
 */

  module: Module,
  method: Schema.String,
  description: Schema.optional(Schema.String),
  cause: Schema.optional(Schema.Defect)
}) {
  /**
   * @since 1.0.0
   */
  readonly [TypeId]: typeof TypeId = TypeId

  /**
   * @since 1.0.0
   */
  get message(): string {
    return `${this.module}.${this.method}${this.description ? `: ${this.description}` : ""}`
  }
}

/**

 */

)

/**

 * @category Model

/**

export class SystemError extends Schema.TaggedError<SystemError>("@effect/platform/Error/SystemError")("SystemError", {
  reason: SystemErrorReason,
  module: Module,
  method: Schema.String,
  description: Schema.optional(Schema.String),

–¶–ï–õ–¨: –°–æ–∑–¥–∞–≤–∞—Ç—å –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏ –¥–æ–∫–∞–∑—É–µ–º—ã–µ —Ä–µ—à–µ–Ω–∏—è —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–æ–Ω–∞–ª—å–Ω—É—é –ø–∞—Ä–∞–¥–∏–≥–º—É —Å –ø–æ–ª–Ω—ã–º —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ–º —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã—Ö –≤—ã—á–∏—Å–ª–µ–Ω–∏–π –∏ –∫–æ–Ω—Ç—Ä–æ–ª–∏—Ä—É–µ–º—ã—Ö —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤.

–ú–û–î–ï–õ–¨ –†–ê–°–°–£–ñ–î–ï–ù–ò–Ø:

  (–∞—Ä—Ö–∏—Ç–µ–∫—Ç–æ—Ä Effect/FP, —Ä–µ–≤—å—é–µ—Ä —Ç–∏–ø–æ–≤, —Å—Ç—Ä–∞–∂ CORE‚ÜîSHELL, —Ç–µ—Å—Ç-–∏–Ω–∂–µ–Ω–µ—Ä).

  –ø–æ –∫—Ä–∏—Ç–µ—Ä–∏—è–º –∏–Ω–≤–∞—Ä–∏–∞–Ω—Ç–æ–≤, —Ç–∏–ø–æ–≤–æ–π –±–µ–∑–æ–ø–∞—Å–Ω–æ—Å—Ç–∏ –∏ —Ç–µ—Å—Ç–∏—Ä—É–µ–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏ (–µ—Å–ª–∏ –ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞—Ç–µ–ª—å —è–≤–Ω–æ –ø—Ä–æ—Å–∏—Ç –≤—ã–±–æ—Ä ‚Äî –≤—ã–±—Ä–∞—Ç—å –∏ –æ–±–æ—Å–Ω–æ–≤–∞—Ç—å).

–ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–û –ü–†–û–¶–ï–°–°–ê (–ù–ï –§–û–†–ú–ê–¢ –û–¢–í–ï–¢–ê):

–õ—é–±–æ–µ —Ä–µ—à–µ–Ω–∏–µ —Å—Ç—Ä–æ–∏—Ç—Å—è –Ω–∞ –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏—Ö –∏–Ω–≤–∞—Ä–∏–∞–Ω—Ç–∞—Ö, –¥–æ–∫–∞–∑—É–µ–º—ã—Ö —Å–≤–æ–π—Å—Ç–≤–∞—Ö –∏ –ø—Ä–æ–≤–µ—Ä—è–µ–º—ã—Ö –∏—Å—Ç–æ—á–Ω–∏–∫–∞—Ö. –ö–æ–¥ —Å–æ–∑–¥–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ —Ñ–æ—Ä–º–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ–≥–æ –ø–æ–Ω–∏–º–∞–Ω–∏—è –ø—Ä–æ–±–ª–µ–º—ã –∏ –ø–æ—Å—Ç—Ä–æ–µ–Ω–∏—è –∞—Ä—Ö–∏—Ç–µ–∫—Ç—É—Ä–Ω–æ–π –º–æ–¥–µ–ª–∏.

–ê–†–•–ò–¢–ï–ö–¢–£–†–ù–´–ï –ü–†–ò–ù–¶–ò–ü–´:
‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏

–ü–†–ò–ù–¶–ò–ü: –°–Ω–∞—á–∞–ª–∞ —Ñ–æ—Ä–º–∞–ª–∏–∑—É–µ–º, –ø–æ—Ç–æ–º –ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º–∏—Ä—É–µ–º.


## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/context-doc/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.text:
**Planning error matching for NotFound**

PlatformError signals NotFound via reason "NotFound" under _tag "SystemError", so detecting this with pattern matching on these fields is feasible. I'll avoid type assertions and use Effect's Match combinators with PlatformError.isPlatformError to safely identify NotFound cases for custom error handling.

**Designing error handling for broken symlinks**

Decided to import type-only PlatformError to define a simple predicate checking for _tag "SystemError" with reason "NotFound" to detect broken symlink errors. I'll modify `readEntry` to catch these errors and return a DirectoryEntry of kind "other," allowing upstream code to skip them gracefully without failing the entire directory read.

**Designing error handling for broken symlinks**

Decided to import type-only PlatformError to define a simple predicate checking for _tag "SystemError" with reason "NotFound" to detect broken symlink errors. I'll modify `readEntry` to catch these errors and return a DirectoryEntry of kind "other," allowing upstream code to skip them gracefully without failing the entire directory read.

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/context-doc/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.text:
**Determining symlink creation approach**

Since the FileSystem interface lacks symlink support and hard links require existing targets, creating broken symlinks necessitates using Node's fs.promises.symlink in tests. I'll wrap this call with Effect.tryPromise to align with the codebase's preference for Effect usage in tests.

**Checking effect-platform for symlink support**

I'm inspecting the internal @effect/platform Node FileSystem implementation to see if it includes symlink functionality.

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

- –ù–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞: `any`, `eslint-disable`, `ts-ignore`
- `unknown`: –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –Ω–∞ boundary (SHELL) –∫–∞–∫ –≤—Ö–æ–¥ –≤ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ (–Ω–∞–ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä, `@effect/schema`);
  –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏–Ω–≥–∞ `unknown` –Ω–µ –¥–æ–ª–∂–µ–Ω –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å –Ω–∞—Ä—É–∂—É boundary-–º–æ–¥—É–ª—è
- `as`: –∑–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â—ë–Ω –≤ –æ–±—ã—á–Ω–æ–º –∫–æ–¥–µ; –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –≤ –æ–¥–Ω–æ–º ‚Äú–∞–∫—Å–∏–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–º‚Äù –º–æ–¥—É–ª–µ (–±—Ä–µ–Ω–¥—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç–æ—Ä—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç–∞–Ω—Ç—ã),
  –¥–∞–ª—å—à–µ –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –±–µ–∑ –∫–∞—Å—Ç–æ–≤
- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞: –∏—Å—á–µ—Ä–ø—ã–≤–∞—é—â–∏–π –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ union types —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `.exhaustive()` / `Match.exhaustive`
- –í–Ω–µ—à–Ω–∏–µ –∑–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–µ–π—Å—ã
- –û—à–∏–±–∫–∏: —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Å–∏–≥–Ω–∞—Ç—É—Ä–∞—Ö —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–π, –Ω–µ runtime exceptions

üß¨ **–ú–û–ù–ê–î–ò–ß–ï–°–ö–ê–Ø –ö–û–ú–ü–û–ó–ò–¶–ò–Ø**:

- Effect-TS –¥–ª—è –≤—Å–µ—Ö —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤: `Effect<Success, Error, Requirements>`
- –ö–æ–º–ø–æ–∑–∏—Ü–∏—è —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `pipe()` –∏ `Effect.flatMap()`

- –û–±—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∫–∞ –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫ –±–µ–∑ try/catch
- –ó–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â–µ–Ω–æ –≤ –ø—Ä–æ–¥—É–∫—Ç-–∫–æ–¥–µ: `async/await`, raw Promise chains (`then/catch`), `Promise.all`
- Interop —Å Promise/–∏—Å–∫–ª—é—á–µ–Ω–∏—è–º–∏ ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –≤ SHELL —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.try` / `Effect.tryPromise` (—Å —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–º –º–∞–ø–ø–∏–Ω–≥–æ–º –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫)
- –†–µ—Å—É—Ä—Å—ã —Å —Ñ–∏–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑–∞—Ü–∏–µ–π ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.acquireRelease` + `Effect.scoped`

–û–ë–Ø–ó–ê–¢–ï–õ–¨–ù–´–ï –¢–†–ï–ë–û–í–ê–ù–ò–Ø:
‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê

1. **–ß–ò–°–¢–û–¢–ê –§–£–ù–ö–¶–ò–ô**:

```typescript
// ‚úÖ –ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - —á–∏—Å—Ç–∞—è —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏—è (–±–µ–∑ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤, –±–µ–∑ –º—É—Ç–∞—Ü–∏–π)
type Money = number

const calculateTotal = (items: ReadonlyArray<Item>): Money =>
  items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)

// ‚ùå –ù–ï–ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - –Ω–∞—Ä—É—à–µ–Ω–∏–µ —á–∏—Å—Ç–æ—Ç—ã

  console.log("Calculating total") // –ü–û–ë–û–ß–ù–´–ô –≠–§–§–ï–ö–¢!
  return items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)
}
```

2. **–§–£–ù–ö–¶–ò–û–ù–ê–õ–¨–ù–´–ï –ö–û–ú–ú–ï–ù–¢–ê–†–ò–ò**:

```typescript
// CHANGE: <–∫—Ä–∞—Ç–∫–æ–µ –æ–ø–∏—Å–∞–Ω–∏–µ –∏–∑–º–µ–Ω–µ–Ω–∏—è>
// WHY: <–º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–µ/–∞—Ä—Ö–∏—Ç–µ–∫—Ç—É—Ä–Ω–æ–µ –æ–±–æ—Å–Ω–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ>
// QUOTE(–¢–ó): "<–¥–æ—Å–ª–æ–≤–Ω–∞—è —Ü–∏—Ç–∞—Ç–∞ —Ç—Ä–µ–±–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏—è>" | n/a
// REF: <REQ-ID –∏–∑ RTM –∏–ª–∏ –Ω–æ–º–µ—Ä —Å–æ–æ–±—â–µ–Ω–∏—è>
// SOURCE: <—Å—Å—ã–ª–∫–∞ —Å –¥–æ—Å–ª–æ–≤–Ω–æ–π —Ü–∏—Ç–∞—Ç–æ–π –∏–∑ –≤–Ω–µ—à–Ω–µ–≥–æ –∏—Å—Ç–æ—á–Ω–∏–∫–∞> | n/a
// FORMAT THEOREM: <‚àÄx ‚àà Domain: P(x) ‚Üí Q(f(x))>
// PURITY: CORE | SHELL - —è–≤–Ω–∞—è –º–∞—Ä–∫–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∫–∞ —Å–ª–æ—è
// EFFECT: Effect<Success, Error, Requirements> - –¥–ª—è shell —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–π
// INVARIANT: <–º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–π –∏–Ω–≤–∞—Ä–∏–∞–Ω—Ç —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏>
// COMPLEXITY: O(time)/O(space) - –≤—Ä–µ–º–µ–Ω–Ω–∞—è –∏ –ø—Ä–æ—Å—Ç—Ä–∞–Ω—Å—Ç–≤–µ–Ω–Ω–∞—è —Å–ª–æ–∂–Ω–æ—Å—Ç—å
```

3. **–°–¢–†–û–ì–ê–Ø –î–û–ö–£–ú–ï–ù–¢–ê–¶–ò–Ø –¢–ò–ü–û–í**:

```typescript
/**
 * –û—Ç–ø—Ä–∞–≤–ª—è–µ—Ç —Å–æ–æ–±—â–µ–Ω–∏–µ –≤ —á–∞—Ç —Å –≥–∞—Ä–∞–Ω—Ç–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω–æ–π –¥–æ—Å—Ç–∞–≤–∫–æ–π
 *
 * @param message - –í–∞–ª–∏–¥–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω–æ–µ —Å–æ–æ–±—â–µ–Ω–∏–µ (–Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º–æ–µ)

 * @returns Effect —Å MessageId –∏–ª–∏ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω–æ–π –æ—à–∏–±–∫–æ–π
 *
 * @pure false - —Å–æ–¥–µ—Ä–∂–∏—Ç —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã –æ—Ç–ø—Ä–∞–≤–∫–∏
 * @effect DatabaseService, NotificationService
 * @invariant ‚àÄm ‚àà Messages: sent(m) ‚Üí ‚àÉid: persisted(m, id)
 * @precondition message.content.length > 0 ‚àß recipients.length > 0
 * @postcondition ‚àÄr ‚àà recipients: notified(r, message) ‚à® error_logged(r)
 * @complexity O(n) where n = |recipients|
 * @throws Never - –≤—Å–µ –æ—à–∏–±–∫–∏ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ Effect
 */
```

4. **–ò–°–ß–ï–†–ü–´–í–ê–Æ–©–ò–ô –ü–ê–¢–¢–ï–†–ù-–ú–ê–¢–ß–ò–ù–ì**:

```typescript
// Switch statements are forbidden in functional programming paradigm.
// How to fix: Use Match with exhaustive coverage.
// Example:
import { Match } from "effect"

type Item = { type: "this" } | { type: "that" }

const result = Match.value(item).pipe(
  Match.when({ type: "this" }, (it) => processThis(it)),
  Match.when({ type: "that" }, (it) => processThat(it)),
  Match.exhaustive
)
```

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/context-doc/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

  –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏–Ω–≥–∞ `unknown` –Ω–µ –¥–æ–ª–∂–µ–Ω –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å –Ω–∞—Ä—É–∂—É boundary-–º–æ–¥—É–ª—è

- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞: –∏—Å—á–µ—Ä–ø—ã–≤–∞—é—â–∏–π –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ union types —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `.exhaustive()` / `Match.exhaustive`
- –í–Ω–µ—à–Ω–∏–µ –∑–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–µ–π—Å—ã

üß¨ **–ú–û–ù–ê–î–ò–ß–ï–°–ö–ê–Ø –ö–û–ú–ü–û–ó–ò–¶–ò–Ø**:

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/context-doc/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.text:
**Analyzing broken symlink handling flaw**

The FileSystemService fails when encountering broken symlinks during directory traversal because fs.stat follows symlinks and errors on missing targets, causing sync to abort; tests can simulate this by adding broken symlinks in a temp directory to verify traversal resilience.

**Planning broken symlink test setup**

I'm outlining a new test that adds a broken symlink inside the codex source to verify sync doesn't fail and files still copy; I'll implement a helper using effect's withFsPath to create the symlink and consider skipping the test on Windows due to symlink permission issues.

on:

jobs:

    steps:

        env:
          GITHUB_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
        shell: bash
        working-directory: packages/app
        run: |
          set +e
          pnpx pkg-pr-new@0.0.24 publish --pnpm --comment=off
          STATUS=$?
          if [ $STATUS -eq 0 ]; then
            echo "success=true" >> "$GITHUB_OUTPUT"
          else
            echo "success=false" >> "$GITHUB_OUTPUT"
            echo "pkg-pr-new failed (likely app not installed); falling back to artifacts."
          fi
          exit 0
      - name: Fallback snapshot artifacts
        if: steps.snapshot.outputs.success != 'true'
        shell: bash
        run: |
          set -euo pipefail
          mkdir -p artifacts
          cd packages/app
          npm pack --silent --pack-destination ../../artifacts
      - name: Upload snapshot artifacts
        if: steps.snapshot.outputs.success != 'true'
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v6
        with:
          name: context-doc-snapshot
          path: artifacts/*.tgz

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/context-doc/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.text:
**Planning file-system update and tests**

I‚Äôm preparing to update file-system logic to handle broken symlinks by adding a helper to detect not-found errors and adjusting error handling. After that, I‚Äôll run the full relevant test suite despite its heaviness to comply with verification requirements.

**Updating file-system to skip broken symlinks and adding targeted test**

I defined a helper to detect NotFound errors and modified `readEntry` to treat missing entries as "other," effectively skipping broken symlinks during traversal. To verify, I‚Äôm extending the sync scenario test setup with a broken symlink creation and adding a new test case that ensures broken symlinks are ignored without aborting sync.

```typescript
import { Match } from "effect"
```

```typescript
      sendMessageUseCase(validCommand),
      Effect.provide(MockMessageRepository),
      Effect.provide(MockNotificationService),
      Effect.tap((messageId) =>
        Effect.sync(() => {
          expect(messageId).toEqual(expectedMessageId)
        })
      ),
      Effect.asVoid
    )
  )
})
```

## Skills
A skill is a set of local instructions to follow that is stored in a `SKILL.md` file. Below is the list of skills that can be used. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions when using a specific skill.
### Available skills
- effect-ts-guide: Teach and apply Effect-TS practices (effect, @effect/schema, @effect/platform) for architecture, typed errors, Layers, dependency injection, resource safety, testing, and migration from async/await/Promise. Use when a user asks how to use Effect, requests best practices, wants to refactor to Effect, or needs mapping from platform modules to Node/Bun/Browser APIs. (file: /home/user/context-doc/.codex/skills/effect-ts-guide/SKILL.md)
- frontend-module-structure: Frontend module architecture and refactoring workflow for React/Vite projects. Use when creating or refactoring frontend pages/features into per-module folders, splitting large files into components/hooks/types/constants, or enforcing the "each module in its own folder" structure (e.g., pages/clients/chats, pages/clients/checks) with functional core vs imperative shell separation. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/frontend-module-structure/SKILL.md)
- mcp-component-preview: Use this skill to explain and apply MCP browser navigation for inspecting UI locally, especially Developer Docs component previews on localhost (e.g., /developer-docs?componentPath=...&exportName=...). Trigger when a user asks how to open, inspect, or verify components via MCP or wants a repeatable flow to validate UI behavior in the browser. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/mcp-component-preview/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /home/user/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
### How to use skills
- Discovery: The list above is the skills available in this session (name + description + file path). Skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description shown above, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deep reference-chasing: prefer opening only files directly linked from `SKILL.md` unless you're blocked.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.text:
**Deciding to use Effect.catchIf**

Plan to handle errors with `Effect.catchIf` from the existing effect library, avoiding switches and updating FileSystemService to treat "not found" errors as "other" with clear comments.

summary.text:
**Deciding to use Effect.catchIf**

Plan to handle errors with `Effect.catchIf` from the existing effect library, avoiding switches and updating FileSystemService to treat "not found" errors as "other" with clear comments.

payload.name: apply_patch
payload.input:
*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: packages/app/src/shell/services/file-system.ts
@@
-import * as FileSystem from "@effect/platform/FileSystem"
+import type { PlatformError as PlatformErrorType } from "@effect/platform/Error"
+import * as FileSystem from "@effect/platform/FileSystem"
 import * as Path from "@effect/platform/Path"
 import { Context, Effect, Layer, pipe } from "effect"
@@
 const entryKindFromInfo = (
   info: FileSystem.File.Info
 ): DirectoryEntryKind => {
@@
 const toDirectoryEntry = (
   path: Path.Path,
   entryPath: string,
   info: FileSystem.File.Info
 ): DirectoryEntry => ({
   name: path.basename(entryPath),
   path: entryPath,
   kind: entryKindFromInfo(info)
 })
 
+const missingEntry = (
+  path: Path.Path,
+  entryPath: string
+): DirectoryEntry => ({
+  name: path.basename(entryPath),
+  path: entryPath,
+  kind: "other"
+})
+
+const isNotFoundError = (error: PlatformErrorType): boolean =>
+  error._tag === "SystemError" && error.reason === "NotFound"
+
+// CHANGE: tolerate missing directory entries while traversing sources
+// WHY: broken symlinks should not abort sync traversal
+// QUOTE(TZ): n/a
+// REF: user-2026-01-21-broken-symlink
+// SOURCE: n/a
+// FORMAT THEOREM: forall e: notFound(e) -> ignored(e)
+// PURITY: SHELL
+// EFFECT: Effect<DirectoryEntry, SyncError, FileSystem>
+// INVARIANT: NotFound entries are classified as kind="other"
+// COMPLEXITY: O(1)/O(1)
 const readEntry = (
   fs: FileSystem.FileSystem,
   path: Path.Path,
   entryPath: string
 ): Effect.Effect<DirectoryEntry, SyncError> =>
   pipe(
     fs.stat(entryPath),
     Effect.map((info) => toDirectoryEntry(path, entryPath, info)),
+    Effect.catchIf(isNotFoundError, () => Effect.succeed(missingEntry(path, entryPath))),
     Effect.mapError(() => syncError(entryPath, "Cannot read directory entry"))
   )
*** End Patch

üèóÔ∏è **FUNCTIONAL CORE, IMPERATIVE SHELL**:

- CORE: –ò—Å–∫–ª—é—á–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∏—Å—Ç—ã–µ —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏, –Ω–µ–∏–∑–º–µ–Ω—è–µ–º—ã–µ –¥–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ, –º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–µ –æ–ø–µ—Ä–∞—Ü–∏–∏
- SHELL: –í—Å–µ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç—ã (IO, —Å–µ—Ç—å, –ë–î, env/process) –∏–∑–æ–ª–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Ç–æ–Ω–∫–æ–π –æ–±–æ–ª–æ—á–∫–µ
- –°—Ç—Ä–æ–≥–æ–µ —Ä–∞–∑–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ: CORE –Ω–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –Ω–µ –≤—ã–∑—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç SHELL
- –ó–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: SHELL ‚Üí CORE (–Ω–æ –Ω–µ –Ω–∞–æ–±–æ—Ä–æ—Ç)

üîí **–¢–ò–ü–û–í–ê–Ø –ë–ï–ó–û–ü–ê–°–ù–û–°–¢–¨**:

- –ù–∏–∫–æ–≥–¥–∞: `any`, `eslint-disable`, `ts-ignore`
- `unknown`: –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –Ω–∞ boundary (SHELL) –∫–∞–∫ –≤—Ö–æ–¥ –≤ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ (–Ω–∞–ø—Ä–∏–º–µ—Ä, `@effect/schema`);
  –ø–æ—Å–ª–µ –¥–µ–∫–æ–¥–∏–Ω–≥–∞ `unknown` –Ω–µ –¥–æ–ª–∂–µ–Ω –≤—ã—Ö–æ–¥–∏—Ç—å –Ω–∞—Ä—É–∂—É boundary-–º–æ–¥—É–ª—è
- `as`: –∑–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â—ë–Ω –≤ –æ–±—ã—á–Ω–æ–º –∫–æ–¥–µ; –¥–æ–ø—É—Å–∫–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –¢–û–õ–¨–ö–û –≤ –æ–¥–Ω–æ–º ‚Äú–∞–∫—Å–∏–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–º‚Äù –º–æ–¥—É–ª–µ (–±—Ä–µ–Ω–¥—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç—Ä—É–∫—Ç–æ—Ä—ã/–∫–æ–Ω—Å—Ç–∞–Ω—Ç—ã),
  –¥–∞–ª—å—à–µ –∏—Å–ø–æ–ª—å–∑–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ –±–µ–∑ –∫–∞—Å—Ç–æ–≤
- –í—Å–µ–≥–¥–∞: –∏—Å—á–µ—Ä–ø—ã–≤–∞—é—â–∏–π –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑ union types —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `.exhaustive()` / `Match.exhaustive`
- –í–Ω–µ—à–Ω–∏–µ –∑–∞–≤–∏—Å–∏–º–æ—Å—Ç–∏: —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä—Ñ–µ–π—Å—ã
- –û—à–∏–±–∫–∏: —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω—ã –≤ —Å–∏–≥–Ω–∞—Ç—É—Ä–∞—Ö —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–π, –Ω–µ runtime exceptions

üß¨ **–ú–û–ù–ê–î–ò–ß–ï–°–ö–ê–Ø –ö–û–ú–ü–û–ó–ò–¶–ò–Ø**:

- Effect-TS –¥–ª—è –≤—Å–µ—Ö —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤: `Effect<Success, Error, Requirements>`
- –ö–æ–º–ø–æ–∑–∏—Ü–∏—è —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `pipe()` –∏ `Effect.flatMap()`

- –û–±—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç–∫–∞ –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫ –±–µ–∑ try/catch
- –ó–∞–ø—Ä–µ—â–µ–Ω–æ –≤ –ø—Ä–æ–¥—É–∫—Ç-–∫–æ–¥–µ: `async/await`, raw Promise chains (`then/catch`), `Promise.all`
- Interop —Å Promise/–∏—Å–∫–ª—é—á–µ–Ω–∏—è–º–∏ ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ –≤ SHELL —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.try` / `Effect.tryPromise` (—Å —Ç–∏–ø–∏–∑–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–Ω—ã–º –º–∞–ø–ø–∏–Ω–≥–æ–º –æ—à–∏–±–æ–∫)
- –†–µ—Å—É—Ä—Å—ã —Å —Ñ–∏–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑–∞—Ü–∏–µ–π ‚Äî —Ç–æ–ª—å–∫–æ —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ `Effect.acquireRelease` + `Effect.scoped`

–û–ë–Ø–ó–ê–¢–ï–õ–¨–ù–´–ï –¢–†–ï–ë–û–í–ê–ù–ò–Ø:
‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê

1. **–ß–ò–°–¢–û–¢–ê –§–£–ù–ö–¶–ò–ô**:

```typescript
// ‚úÖ –ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - —á–∏—Å—Ç–∞—è —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏—è (–±–µ–∑ —ç—Ñ—Ñ–µ–∫—Ç–æ–≤, –±–µ–∑ –º—É—Ç–∞—Ü–∏–π)
type Money = number

const calculateTotal = (items: ReadonlyArray<Item>): Money =>
  items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)

// ‚ùå –ù–ï–ü–†–ê–í–ò–õ–¨–ù–û - –Ω–∞—Ä—É—à–µ–Ω–∏–µ —á–∏—Å—Ç–æ—Ç—ã

  console.log("Calculating total") // –ü–û–ë–û–ß–ù–´–ô –≠–§–§–ï–ö–¢!
  return items.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0)
}
```

2. **–§–£–ù–ö–¶–ò–û–ù–ê–õ–¨–ù–´–ï –ö–û–ú–ú–ï–ù–¢–ê–†–ò–ò**:

```typescript
// CHANGE: <–∫—Ä–∞—Ç–∫–æ–µ –æ–ø–∏—Å–∞–Ω–∏–µ –∏–∑–º–µ–Ω–µ–Ω–∏—è>
// WHY: <–º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–æ–µ/–∞—Ä—Ö–∏—Ç–µ–∫—Ç—É—Ä–Ω–æ–µ –æ–±–æ—Å–Ω–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ>
// QUOTE(–¢–ó): "<–¥–æ—Å–ª–æ–≤–Ω–∞—è —Ü–∏—Ç–∞—Ç–∞ —Ç—Ä–µ–±–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏—è>" | n/a
// REF: <REQ-ID –∏–∑ RTM –∏–ª–∏ –Ω–æ–º–µ—Ä —Å–æ–æ–±—â–µ–Ω–∏—è>
// SOURCE: <—Å—Å—ã–ª–∫–∞ —Å –¥–æ—Å–ª–æ–≤–Ω–æ–π —Ü–∏—Ç–∞—Ç–æ–π –∏–∑ –≤–Ω–µ—à–Ω–µ–≥–æ –∏—Å—Ç–æ—á–Ω–∏–∫–∞> | n/a
// FORMAT THEOREM: <‚àÄx ‚àà Domain: P(x) ‚Üí Q(f(x))>
// PURITY: CORE | SHELL - —è–≤–Ω–∞—è –º–∞—Ä–∫–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∫–∞ —Å–ª–æ—è
// EFFECT: Effect<Success, Error, Requirements> - –¥–ª—è shell —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–π
// INVARIANT: <–º–∞—Ç–µ–º–∞—Ç–∏—á–µ—Å–∫–∏–π –∏–Ω–≤–∞—Ä–∏–∞–Ω—Ç —Ñ—É–Ω–∫—Ü–∏–∏>
// COMPLEXITY: O(time)/O(space) - –≤—Ä–µ–º–µ–Ω–Ω–∞—è –∏ –ø—Ä–æ—Å—Ç—Ä–∞–Ω—Å—Ç–≤–µ–Ω–Ω–∞—è —Å–ª–æ–∂–Ω–æ—Å—Ç—å
```
